commentBody: If it ain't BAROQUE, don't fix it.
Great Tuesday theme, quite a giggle. And loved the clue for 18-down

Our columnist writes:
57A. When I got to [Daddy-o], I already had P as the first letter. I thought it could be PAPA...

...but that would be unlikely since 35D is PAPABEARS.
"Baroque" is not a "genre," but a period or style, right?

"Do you like my cantata?"
"Ugh. I'm sonata fan."

("But it's my aria of expertise!")

Tales from a struggling composer‚Ä¶

Who says the ORATORIO is only from the Baroque? I‚Äôve written an edgy new one featuring ORION (bass) and an ALBINO RAT (soprano).

Oh what a SNAFU! The two themes I wanted to use in this FUGUE just don‚Äôt work together. Must I start over? GUESS SO!

My PERSONA as an influential composer has taken a hit with my latest SONATA. It‚Äôs so bad it may need a TAE BO kick to the curb.

PDQ Bach was Baroque, right? I‚Äôm emulating him in this new CHORALE, which tells the drama of LURCH standing for his ORAL EXAMS in algebraic topology.

What kind of wood did they use in 17th century Europe for making tabletops in drinking establishments? 

Bar oak.
Even my college freshmen in music appreciation know the difference between an ERA and a GENRE.
The only thing that didn't compute for me with this puzzle is that the clues didn't seem to display even the tiniest attempt to mislead. Thusly I wonder how come it's run as a Tuesday puzzle.

While I play French Horn I never took music appreciation so Baroque was a guess that could have ba roke me. Ok, bad pun. I‚Äôd have loved to have seen John Williams clued as a truly great composer. S.A.G. at 32A was a nice break from the usual clues, and for me a gimme especially since I just learned Robert Duvall one of its outstanding members died yesterday. Baroque my heart. However 3:45 under my average is very nice

The classical music nerd in me lit up when I saw FUGUE. Great puzzle!

FWIW, my personal favorite will always be the conclusion to Beethoven op. 110.

What an elegant puzzle to solve tonight. I enjoyed reading the constructor notes as well. The theme brought the following song to mind‚Ä¶ Boulevard of Broke(n) Dreams üòâ https://youtu.be/Soa3gO7tL-c?si=0kaaOlxRKY7QWZyt Happy Tuesday everyone!
Great Tuesday puzzle, thank you!

A puzzle that brings together music and words is always a hit with me.

Thank you so much, Stephan and Jeff.
The way you peppered it all with musical bits beyond the themers is quite a feat. Loved it!
Thought I would chime in with a Bach-Handel compliment on the puzzle.
Very well composed Tuesday puzzle. I enjoyed the theme and the rest of the fill. I loved the finger painting clue!

The BBQ side dish reminded me of decades ago when the best place around (I will start a debate here) was Dreamland BBQ in Tuscaloosa, Alabama. In the beginning they not only didn't have side dishes but would look at you like you were raised by wolves if you asked. They would provide sliced white bread but that's all. Anything else besides the meat and sauce was basically sacrilegious.

I struggle with Sam's puzzles. For me they are way too US centric. I have no idea who a lot of the references are indicating. People and teams from another culture. A shame they aren't constructed in a more globally friendly way.

A fun and delightfully straightforward puzzle! And to everyone else putting on a PERSONA for visiting family as they ask what you've been UP TO and PAN all the choices you've made last year, or getting ready to SATE yourself on all the festive snacks, a very happy LUNAR NEW YEAR from my corner of the world! üî•üê¥üß®
I really enjoyed ‚ÄúBoot out of Europe?‚Äù And ‚ÄúSome fancy finger painting‚Äù

Sorry, those music items are found from the 17th through the 21st century.  They are not only Baroque!

You could have fixed the clue,,,,
I play an instrument, but Baroque music never interested me as much as music from other periods. It was nice seeing my knowledge come in handy for this puzzle, though!

userLocation: Spring Hill, just south of Armageddon
commentBody: Dang if I'm not becoming even more fond of show-off themes which are barely needed for or entirely incidental to the solve.

I noticed the theme when I had filled in about half of the circled letters. I then stopped and filled in the rest of the circled letters, which I think helped me obtain a time that was 35% faster than average.
I loved this on every level, especially the constructor‚Äôs notes and the parallels he presented between crossword puzzles and music. Bravo, Mr. Prock
ALIENORAT sounded so much cooler, but maybe I need to go outside and touch some grass.

I was excited to see a familiar name, Hrishikesh Hirway, for today‚Äôs columnist. I am familiar with him from the delightful podcast he does with the genius chef, Samin Nosrat, Home Cooking. https://homecooking.show I don‚Äôt know if this is the first time he has written here but, based on today‚Äôs column, I‚Äôd look forward to reading him again. Great job on the column, Hrishi! I enjoyed the puzzle, too, although I didn‚Äôt get the baroque pun until I read the column.

Of course I did not understand how the revealer could be interpreted as funny. I needed the column to explain it to me. Do "broke" and "baroque" really sound the same in American English? I guess if I try to pronounce "broke" in a sassy way, it sort of does sound like "baroque".

My solve was somewhat faster than my Tuesdsy average, but judging by how I needed a couple of across and down passes to fill the grid, it wasn't all that easy. It felt quite interesting for an early week puzzle, which rarely happens. My curmodgeonly persona won't rear its se√óy head today. Am I ACTing NORMAL when I'm not being critical?

A few years ago the NE corner would have stumped me - it was quite trivia-heavy, and I only learned IAMS from previous puzzles at the NYT.

I suppose pearl clutchers will be ABASHed by SNAFU?

"Nobody doesn't like SARA Lee" is exactly the kind of slogan that would make me never touch whatever it is they sell ü§£

I just did the puzzle but I am currently too tired to look through the comments, so apologies if this has been brought up. It's not exactly 36 down, but it's one of my favorite parts of Parks and Rec. https://youtu.be/aswgTPlzazo?si=OBvnl1NBRKoiwnQh ü§£ Off to bed!
Clever puzzle TY
What a beautiful puzzle. I finished it wanting more from this collaboration.

My first Tuesday with no help needed! 
This was easier than yesterday's for me. The pet food IAMS is available here and I just bought some. 

As a great fan of Renaissance and Baroque music, it was nice to see the theme instead of having to struggle with rappers.

Very pleasing.

Meh
If you don't understand or know music, this became a themeless. I needed to read the column to understand the theme, but wasn't that impressed by the punniness. Oh well, tomorrow is another day
I can‚Äôt think of BAROQUE without thinking of the oldest US President, Baroque Obama
I enjoyed today's puzzle and it's word play (Boot out of Italy). Theme was clever for a Tuesday. I was amused by constructor's attempt to compare crossword construction with musical composition!üòä
I really went for BAROQUE on this cutie pie.  Also enjoyed today's guest columnist.

This frightened me a little with how few I had on the first acros pass and I thought I was in for a disaster, but the first down pass filled out a lot.
Enjoyed several of the clues in it.
I was wondering what TAE BO is, looked it up and some long-dormant parts of my memory were dragged out of their coma. We even had those infomercials over here.

[What resulted from a muscle pull when a big lovable guy ran too fast]



PAIN IN THE GALOOT

If it ain‚Äôt baroque, 
then grab a Roquefort and some wine
and sit down to watch it decompose.


(And if you are broke, you could have some cash WIRED, use the ATMS, or throw ABASH on your behalf.)

Fun.

NAILART was last to fall for me. I definitely had pigeonholed that clue to mean some form of fine art and I was wracking my brain for avant-garde terminology from my (relatively infrequent) visits to museums. I only "got it" after revealing the entire answer via the crosses...

Hah!  What a terrific theme.  It employs a visual element ‚Äì a black square splitting a word, a riddle (What do the circled words have in common?) that is perfectly answered by the revealer, and silliness in said revealer.

And it may be so tight that it‚Äôs a one-one-of-a-kind.  Someone out there, please, prove me wrong by coming up with another one that fulfills all these conditions!

I gotta tell ya, when I uncovered BAROQUE, I baroque into a huge smile. I also loved row twelve with its unlikely rhyme of SARA and FRERE (as sung in ‚ÄúFrere Jacques‚Äù).  

This quirky and silly theme upped my mood from neutral to tickled, and therefore to grateful.  Thank you, Stephan and Jeff!

Nicely constructed Tuesday puzzle, with a robust and well-handled theme and revealer (unlike yesterday).

Seeing ALBANIA-- directly *west* of a correctly oriented ITALY was a bit unsettling geographically, but on the whole the fill was interesting enough.

Still looking for the Adriatic ...

I blew through this puzzle, with the only minor hitch for a nanosecond being the name of the physicist. Once I got the first themer, the others just flowed, and I was pretty much on autopilot. When I got to the end, I thought "Hmm, this puzzle needs a revealer." Then I looked over my answers, and one of them nearly BAROQUE me.
I baroque out a smile for this one.
Fun puzzle. Really enjoyed the column today, too.

I love puns and didn't have any trouble with this one, perhaps inspired by a friend years ago who was in a band called "Going Baroque". Not a pop or ska band!

More to the point, and why I came to comment, I quite enjoyed the column today. Let's have Hrishikesh Hirway write it regularly now.

As your resident alphadoppeltotter, a role I‚Äôve inexplicably taken in the past eight years, it is my duty to inform you that this puzzle has an unusually low number of double letters, at four, where unusual is any number less than five. This is the second time this year that this has happened. 

I remain your humble servant, ever on the alert.
Fun, fun, fun makes me want to hum! Just enough interesting clues to make me think without getting the blues Thank you for a great puzzle!

Lovely Tuesday puzzle.  Amusi(c)ing theme.  Clever revealer.  Solid fill.

See!  Isn't it nicer with a clever revealer?
Just sayin'.

Although the nitpicker in me is compelled to note that the phrase "IF IT AIN'T BAROQUE..." has exactly 15 letters.
Just sayin'.

My mother had to hide
sweets from her four children 
if there was *any* hope 
they would last until company arrived.

But we knew.
And we were determined.

So one evening 
when her bridge friends
came over she was searching
for the sweets she'd bought.

No luck.

We found them
three weeks later
when the snow melted.

She'd hidden the Sara Lee goodies
and some chocolates in a snowdrift
in the yard.

Crafty little Swede...

Well, this is weird.  I was working on a puzzle yesterday, and got stuck on two boxes, so I put it aside for later.   

Working on today's NYT, I got to the clue for 15 A, and thought, "Hmm, that looks familiar".

Back to the puzzle I was stuck on. 

I was missing an I and an M and the answer was Idomeneo.

It almost felt like cheating when I was able to fill it right in.

Seconding what someone said below: without a musical background this becomes effectively a themeless puzzle with a difficult to ascertain theme and the revealer entry tucked away in the middle. Having PAULI as the linchpin of the SW corner also made that corner pretty impenetrable and required a look up. Didn‚Äôt love either of those aspects of this puzzle.

The rest, though, I adored. The cluing felt intuitive without giving too much away. The topics covered were diverse and varied, with some reused clues for familiar solvers and new ones alike. The longer entries were fun and very fairly clued in my opinion. Overall I had a great time with this one.

Happy Tuesday!
I loved the puzzle, and the constructor notes were the pi√®ce de r√©sistance.

I'm no expert in music, classical or otherwise, but I did teach a course on Western Civilization that had a unit on BAROQUE music. Polyphonic music is hard to "get" for the inexperienced audience, so I would use this video that "diagrams" Bach's "Little FUGUE in g minor". It seemed to help. So for your enjoyment and edification, I present this candidate for earworm of the day: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ddbxFi3-UO4

A more sophisticated, smoother puzzle than you usually see on Tuesdays -- even though I'll never be a fan of tiny little embedded circles no matter how elegant the embedded words might be and how elegantly embedded they are.

I initially came here to look at the Constructor's Notes -- specifically to see what Jeff Chen would  say about collaborating on a Tuesday.  He didn't have a whole lot to say.  But I found Stephen Prock's remarks absolutely fascinating --and extremely relevant to my own life.  Specifically to my experience as both a non-grid-making puzzle constructor and as a lyricist who can't write music.  

Stephen discusses how the demands of writing music are highly similar to making a grid -- and he gives specifics.  (There go my chances of ever doing either one!)  I found his comments extremely interesting and think many other people here will find them interesting too.  I recommend reading them.

I love listening to classical music, but I don't know much about the actual composition of it. Much of the constructor notes whizzed right over my head and into the neighbor's yard.

Thankfully, I didn't need that knowledge to solve the puzzle! It was enough to know words like FUGUE and SONATA, even if I can't define them.

Excellent puzzle, and excellent column! I bet today's going to be an excellent day.

If it‚Äôs not BAROQUE don‚Äôt fix it.

Loved this grid, despite being musically tone deaf; too many years spent pogoing to punk.

Concerning the connection between music and crosswords, I remember a scene from the movie "Wordplay" from 2006 (twenty years ago?!?) in which one of the champion cruciverbalists related how his career as a pianist gave him the ability to simultaneously look at the treble and bass clefs of the written music while doing something independently with his hands.  This was a skill that helped him become one of the best at crossword times.

I had thought that I was a good solver, but I knew then and there that I would NEVER be a championship-level solver.

Nice Tuesday puzzle and an enjoyable workout. Didn't really catch on to the theme until I was almost done, but that's always a nice touch. 

And... puzzle finds today were inspired by a search for BAROQUE. And yeah - it's been part of the theme in a number of puzzles. Here are some examples. I'm just going to list the answers (not the clues) and not link to the puzzles.

....

Am I an existential threat to the Column?

What clever cluing for this wonderful Tuesday grid, Stephan and Jeff! I enjoyed every bit of it -- HANdS down! 

Happy Tuesday, everyone!
That was amazingly smooth! So many callbacks to the theme, and just effortless wordplay in the clueing. Well done!
I got the music theme almost immediately, but although I love Baroque music, I had to get the revealer from the crosses. Never mind, it was a fun solve anyway!

This theme made me happy!  I'm in a choral group and we've sung a fair amount of Baroque music over the years.  Those FU GUEs can be quite challenging.  

Temps will be over  40 for the next few days and we are slowly emerging from the frozen tundra.

Thanks Stephan and Jeff for a fun puzzle!

I liked today's puzzle; just a small quibble though, shouldn't 38-Down be clued as an abbreviation? Given that it's [Sandwiches often on toasted bread] without a hint of initialism, I originally had BETS or BATS thinking it was a kind of sandwich I was unaware of (the Ford offering across was of little help to me).
SINCE and BECAUSE are not synonyms.  SINCE is used to indicate temporal relationships while BECAUSE is used to indicate cause-and-effect relationships.

Nice to get a little music education with my morning coffee & crossword. An hourglass filled with sand brings to mind the classic opening for the soap opera "Days of Our Lives." Here's a link if you're curious - https://youtu.be/Og7-6YubuS4?si=KOv2nNIEe_1AaE7o
ORION is also an instrumental piece by Metallica. And the amp in the column photo looks like my old Marshall.
Never commented on a crossword puzzle before, but I just loved this one. Just the right kind of wordplay without, to my mind, any fussy ones or that's-a-stretch-es.
Quick to solve that one, 10 minutes and 10 minutes faster than usual too. No lookups. Pleased with myself!

the night hunter

furtive, quick
someone‚Äôs name‚Ä¶

for nobody

who stored the knives
in a cart

in a a/ fist

Great puzzle! I‚Äôd heard the Sara Lee commercial hundreds of times in the 80s and 90s, but until today I always thought it was ‚Äúno one does it like Sara Lee‚Äù! The ultra-processed ‚Äúfood‚Äù they make is garbage, of course -

One more puzzle find. A Sunday from July 13, 2014 by Tom McCoy with the title: "We hold these truths to be self-evident." Today‚Äôs theme made me think of the old one-liner, "I just can‚Äôt get a Handel on all these Baroque jokes."

(Handel was a baroque composer.)

A puzzle after my own heart! Most of this was already brought up by Hrishikesh in his column, but it's worth pointing out how the clue for 15A mentions tow operas which arguably bookend the Baroque Era in music--here's the opening Toccata from *L'Orfeo*, ushering in the Baroque with a blaze of D major: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mjpFi9bn1do&list=RDmjpFi9bn1do&start_radio=1 Here's Pato Banton RAPping with Ranking Roger of the SKA band The English Beat (except in ska, they call it "toasting": https://https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WwJ3XE_2INM&list=RDWwJ3XE_2INM&start_radio=1 Finally, here's "Variation 15" from Hans Zimmer's soundtrack to *Dunkirk*--this is the best vid I could find which shows how effectively the soundtrack is used in the movie: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vtibK6xBBiE&list=RDvtibK6xBBiE&start_radio=1 Thank you, thank you Stephan and Jeff!

Enjoyed this puzzle as an amateur musician and appreciator of classical music. Shout-out to the delightful Sandra Boynton, illustrator of Gopher BAROQUE: https://www.simonandschuster.com/books/Gopher-Baroque/Sandra-Boynton/Boynton-for-Puzzlers/9781665938556
Fun puzzle with a clever theme! Solved in under 10 minutes but got a little stuck in the NE corner‚Ä¶ always tough when 2 names intersect and I don‚Äôt know either one!
Delighted to know that Stephan Prock, co-author of today's puzzle, is a composer of classical music. Thanks, Stephan. I am enjoying visiting your website: https://www.stephanprock.com

Two stories about Pauli.

There is the Pauli Principle, which is fundamental quantum mechanics.  There is the Pauli Effect, which has never been explained, that as a theoretician his presence would ruin any experiment.  One group had an experiment completely collapse mysteriously, then started working again.  They later found Pauli was on a train passing through the town at that point

Apparently Pauli was quite delighted with his brilliance.  He, like a lot of physicists, wondered if there was a relationship between fundamental constants, like the mass and charge of an electron.  He died, went to heaven, and God explained it to him.

He thought for a few minutes, and said, "No, no, no.  That can't be right."
Magnificat, er, I mean magnificent puzzle. A virtuoso performance by its creator.
ha ha. who's never heard that one?

And... one more late puzzle find. A Sunday from March 3, 2013 by Samuel A. Donaldson with the title: "Seven blurbs for seven biographies." A couple of theme clue and answer examples: "An insightful look at how playing Miss Brooks took its toll on Ms. Arden" THEDESTRUCTIONOFEVE "It's worth it just for Ms. Behar's famous lasagna recipe" THECOOKINGOFJOY And some other theme answers: THESPADESOFJACK THETIMEOFNICK THERIGHTSOFBILL THEDARKNESSOFPRINCE THEWARFAREOFART Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/3/2013&g=103&d=A ...

I'm very late to the party. Just wanted to say that I loved this theme! Very clever and cute.

As a professional orchestral conductor (at the collegiate level), I very much enjoyed the theme! And as Cogsworth once said, "if it ain't Baroque, don't fix it!" Though I will argue that SONATA form is really from the Classical era rather than the BAROQUE era...

A day late to the party but I wanted to thank the constructors for this lovely puzzle! The highlight for me was ACH right beside the revealer BAROQUE. Almost BACH! Made me swoon at little. Hach (German happy sigh)

commentBody: @Barry Ancona that's assuming they solve accurately in numeric order

Adin,
Once upon a time, the "Tricky Clues" section was supposed to provide teaching moments for new solvers. 57A would have been a good time to note that major words are almost never repeated in the grid except in support of a theme.
https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/genre

@Jonathan All categories are up for debate. I think it could be seen as a genre or sub-genre, along with being a period or style. In my personal music collection, I make it a sub-genre, with the genre title ‚Äúclassical-baroque,‚Äù with ‚Äúclassical‚Äù meaning the large category of music that basically includes everything likely to be played on a classical radio station, running from early renaissance music through music written in the 21st century, as opposed to true classical music, like the music written by W.A. Mozart and F.J. Haydn., which gets the genre ‚Äúclassical-classical‚Äù in my collection.

@Justin Kalm

Genres are like, sonata, concerto, oratorio, fugue; landscape, portrait; novel, short story, epic poem; sonnet.  Periods or styles can include several genres.  For example, the suite is a genre of baroque music, but baroque itself is not a genre in this sense. There are operas in many period of music, baroque operas, romantic operas. Opera is the genre, romantic is the style or period.  Of course, in popular modes we talk of country or rock as genres, too.

@Mike
The tenor of your claim is alto familiar, but on what do you bass it?  (I've heard this song before.)
@Mike You conduct yourself like a one man choir, with all those pitch-perfect zingers (er‚Ä¶ beautifully zinging zongs)

Mike,

Yeah, your cantata‚Äôs not great - 
but you did an ok chorale.


(Fugue! At least that old pun‚Äôs out of the way now!)

@Cat Lady Margaret Even the oddest of J.S. Bach's 23-odd sons never constrained himself the way many modern composers do: all chords must be dissonant, and the top number in the time signature, if there even is one, must be a prime number greater than three!

Now I must get back to constructing my pianofort.
@Music prof same difference

@Becky M 
The Baroque Era was roughly 1600-1750. Genres during that era include the terms in the crossword. We wouldn‚Äôt refer to the entire 20th century as a single genre, so we don‚Äôt do that either music from the Baroque Era either.

@Dan

I'd guess it tested as Tuesday difficulty.

@Heidi

I like that theory. It's similar to how one grades climbing routes in Poland.

I - no climbing involved: you can do this walking on your feet and never using your hands
II - some use of handholds necessary but only some of the time (think a steep hiking trail high in the mountains)
III - ladder-style route: use of handholds required at all times yet the whole thing can be done in a frontal position without any actual climbing technique
IV - basic climbing technique required
V - advanced use of basic climbing technique required
V+ - basic use of advanced climbing technique required
VI - advanced climbing technique required

Etc.

@Dan

Agreed. To me, this put up less resistance than most Mondays.

commentBody:
@Francis
LOL
Ask yourself why Gypsy Rose Lee wore gloves when she stripped. (Hint: not because she suffered from poor circulation in her extremities.)
Or why the traditional token from a lady to her knight was a glove.
Contra Freud: Sometimes a cigar is more than just a cigar.

@Leontion

For a long time our only counterpart of your BBQ places were grilled kie≈Çbasa stands. For the base price you got the kie≈Çbasa and a dollop each of ketchup and mustard. There were only two optional extras - kajzerka (a German-style wheat roll which has become a staple at our bakeries - before 1989 it was the only kind of roll you could buy) and og√≥rek kiszony (cucumber pickled in brine, without any vinegar - another Polish staple). That's it. No salads, no fancy sauces.

I loved those simple kie≈Çbasa stands. When I was a kid my parents and I always stopped at one on our family bike rides and long walks. The stand we ate at most often was in Powsin, a village on the edge of Warsaw's Kabacki forest. It was there for decades but 15 years ago or so it disappeared, no longer able to withstand competitors from fancier dining options. It still makes me sad.

These days kie≈Çbasa stands survive almost exclusively at roadside rest areas, but as our roads are transformed into modern highways, those places keep vanishing, too, supplanted by soulless cafeterias at gas stations.

userLocation: Spring training again. Ahh, at last! ‚öæÔ∏è
commentBody:
@Andrzej
For many years, there was a _heavily_ garlicked commercial dill pickle called 'Polski Ogorki'. My Polish mother, who abandoned pickle-making  (she had enough to do, believe me! though she still made jams), was a loyal consumer. If, by some bizarre and completely unimaginable mischance, you had no garlic in the house, a rinsed and chopped Polski Ogorki was a perfect substitute.
@Andrzej Kielbasa with a side of Cole Slaw would be delish‚Ä¶

@SBK

While some garlic is always used in the brine, classic Polish kiszone og√≥rki never actively taste of it. Whatever it was that Americans sold as 'Polskie og√≥rki' (Polish cucumbers) just was not very Polish at all.

The traditional Polish 'zestaw do kiszenia [og√≥rk√≥w]' ('pickling set'), which you can buy at the shops and farmer's markets, includes several fennel flowers with stalks, a roughly sliced horseraddish root, and a head of garlic. Flavorings include mustard seeds, laurel leaves and a few grains of allspice.

Some people swear by additional ingredients. For example, the lady I always buy from at my local farmer's market always adds Polish oak leaves from a tree on her land  to her kiszone og√≥rki brine.

My wife won't even touch kiszone og√≥rki that taste too heavily of any of the other ingredients - she's a traditionalist in that way.

I personally like kiszone og√≥rki brined with chili peppers on top of everything else for a bit of kick - they appeared on the market in recent decades. My wife frowns at the very idea.

@MB

That's just it - kie≈Çbasa and kiszony og√≥rek is such a classic pairing I just can't imagine it with anything else.

I first had coleslaw at KFC in London in 1993. I liked it. At the time it had not yet arrived in Poland - that happened later, probably in the late 1990s.

Still, it's no proper accompaniament for kie≈Çbasa, and certainly not at a traditional kie≈Çbasa stand :)
@Andrzej Nothing quite as good as a Polish kie≈Çbasa at a county fair.

@Steve L

That would be considered an unusual combo over here - we eat pierogi as a standalone dish, sometimes with a side salad (one we would call a sur√≥wka, so generally not leafy like a sa≈Çatka, but rather made of diced or grated vegetables, likely including fresh cabbage and carrots). 

Pierogi are never a side dish here. A small portion might serve as a starter though.

Fried kie≈Çbasa with a side of potatoes/bread and sur√≥wka/og√≥rek kiszony would be another standalone dish.

I get why you do it like you do - it's just that it's not how we would traditionally do it over here. Isn't it interesting how culture and what we are used to affects us? What you're doing is perfectly fine, yet an average Pole would raise an eyebrow at it.

Pierogi are brilliant when you need a quick dinner or lunch, aren't they? They are so ubiquitous we generally don't freeze them as you can buy them fresh anywhere. All it takes is several minutes in hot water (or in a frying pan) and voila.

@Andrzej

So you also eat potatoes with kielbasa, but
not inside a pastry. 

When we don‚Äôt have pierogi handy, we might make mashed potatoes instead, too. 

I think that if pierogi are a standalone dish in Poland, it may be a holdover from the times of little choice before the fall of Communism. Unless there are a lot of vegetarians in Poland.

Steve "So you also eat potatoes with kielbasa, but not inside a pastry." Pretty much :D What can I say other than: it's tradition. Traditions rarely are rational, in a modern context, anyway. Also, as I understand it when you write "pierogi" you actually mean a very specific kind: since you mention potatoes, apparently we're speaking of "pierogi ruskie" (pierogi of Rus - not Russia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rus%27_people ), stuffed with a paste of potato and onion. Over here "pierogi" is a generic name, never implying any specific filling. We have many kinds: with minced meat, ruskie, with saurkraut and mushrooms, and more recently with spinach and cheese. Our pierogi portion sizes are typically large, at 200 to 400g per person. There is nothing vegetarian about our pierogi, even when they are not filled with meat: traditionally pierogi were always served with skwarki, tiny bits of crackling and the pork fat from the crackling's frying. Historically you're right, of course. This was a poor country for centuries, and people rarely ate meat, but many had access to flour and potatoes - it was only natural pierogi became a staple of a main dish. I've literally never seen pierogi on the same plate with anything else than sur√≥wka.

commentBody:
@winterlong

I imagine people from Mongolia and Uruguay are even more strapped than you when it comes to the US-centricity of the NEW YORK Times puzzle...

@MattüòÉ
For sure.
The Spelling Bee can also be teicky.
I never heard of a Barback before.
And so many other words they use.
But handy because then I'll know them when they come up in the mini puzzle.üòõ

Sure, but when you seem them often enough, you being remembering even the things you don't care about. Would you believe I'm actually occasionally able to recall what US sport team comes from which city? It also works with American slang and idioms, and those are quite fun and useful things to learn. Now that I know them, I keep hearing them in old series I'm rewatching - apparently originally they did not register, and now I actually understand them. It's quite cool to realize.

The brands are the most annoying entries, aren't they? As a countercapitalist I feel defeated each time I remember a brand but what can you do... buying from big brands is the worst offence, knowing them alone is forgivable.

@winterlong
Are you commenting on a different day‚Äôs puzzle? Today‚Äôs was constructed by Stephen (Prock) and Jeff (Chen), not ‚ÄúSam.‚Äù There also weren‚Äôt any sports teams in today‚Äôs puzzle, and the specific members of Homo sapiens consisted of a (fictional) Australian, a Brit, a German, and an Austrian.

As for today‚Äôs puzzle, I was surprised to find out how many of the proper nouns that might be US-centric are apparently also a thing in Australia: IAMS, NERF, OLAY (probably less of a surprise), and even SARA Lee (though no clue if that specific slogan had any antipodean use; I don‚Äôt think I‚Äôd ever heard it before myself).

I guess maybe the following could truly be considered US-centric: DEN (regional in the US, as well), SLAW, EDSEL, LURCH, LEI, and ALOHA.

See*

Begin*

What does autocorrect even do...

commentBody:
@Elaine

The clue is perfectly valid.

Crossword clues do not need to be all encompassing or all defining.

They just need to accurately describe their fill.

You are correct to point out that ORATORIOs, FUGUEs, SONATAs and CHORALEs are hardly the exclusive purview of baroque music.

However, they are all prominent features of baroque music.

Which is all that's required to allow the clue to hold.

commentBody:
Would Andrzej happily eat frozen cheesecake?

No, not necesSaraLee

@Matt

That's way too elegant an explanation. It can't possibly be true, if only because elegance is not punny and the constructors wanted us to interpret the revealer as a groaner.

@Bill in Yokohama

I'll just go ahead and ignore the groaner as I still would like to respect you ü§£

Is that what they make? I'm way too much of a food snob to eat any cake that's been mass-produced. I'll see you at my local artisanal cafe and bakery. If it's bad for me let it at least be the best it can.

Knowing American "cheese" and lack of standards in food regulation, I can't even begin to imagine the horror of an industrially made US cheesecake...

@Andrzej - the slogan made me think of saragli (the rolled baklava) and I have to say that in that case, no matter how bad the slogan, I'd be tempted. Alas, after a quick google Sara Lee seems to have nothing to do with Greek/Turkish desserts soaked in syrup. Waste of a good name.

If an American coroporation industrially made it (in a facility where nobody gets paid vacation time or maternity/paternity leave), the ingredients list would be three pages long and to understand it you'd need a degree in both organic and inorganic chemistry. The syrup would be the cheapest high fructose kind. There would be no butter but instead artificially flavored palm oil, sourced from the least environmentally friendly plant someplace where a hundred organgutangs per acre died to deforestation and a species of endemic frog actually went extinct. Etc.

@MB

Why sorry? I love when Americans explain their language and culture to me, and share personal experiences.

The funny thing is, while before 1989 we were all poor and shops were extremely badly stocked, what was on sale was generally quite decent in quality. For example, sweets contained real butter or (quite healthy, as oils go) rapeseed oil, real sugar (rather than those horrid corn syrups), etc.

In the 1990s most of our industry was sold off to Western investors, who now produce cheaply made slop under old, once respectable Polish brands. It's quite sad. Luckily some supermarkets have realized people actually want quality, so you can get decent chocolate even at a local Lidl. We have loads of artisanal bakeries and cafes, too.

I am allergic to all advertising. These days I only stream music and video so I don't see any ads other than bilboards when I'm out on the town. When I'm occasionally exposed to radio and tv, the advertising jingles, cheap slogans and pseudo-music make me want to scream. How, *how* can anybody be tempted to buy anything by *that*? I just don't get it. I buy stuff because I like the quality (as demonstrated by the ingredients list on the label, say), not because some disembodied voice on the radio told me to.

Not sorry for rambling :D

@Andrzej Totally agree. I haven‚Äôt had a slice of Sara Lee poundcake in 40 years, so I have no idea what it‚Äôs like now. When I was in my late teens and early twenties, and probably in the throes of PMS, it was delightful. Especially after a supper of broiled steak, Tater Tots, and salad. Woof. Yeah. The real baked stuff is sooo much better. 

As for advertising, as I mentioned, I believe the height of creativity, especially with cheeky humor, was the 60s and 70s. Then all those wonderful Madison Avenue agencies got bought up and became mega-agencies where the money flowed, but in my opinion, the smart wit did not. I blame it on Reagan. Much as I blame a lot on him. But we‚Äôll not go there today.

@MB Sara Lee is one of the few American brands of sweet stuff that goes down well in the UK. Their double chocolate gateau. Mm. So "Nobody doesn't like" works better for that brand than for Hershey's, for example I suppose the other US brand of sweet stuff that is big in the UK is Mars. But some of their products were developed in the UK.

@Heidi

This gem of a comment brings to mind many a Seinfeld vignette ‚Äî eminently safe from the Emu‚Äôs chompers, yet far more risqu√© than any number of comments said Emu would chomp up without a second‚Äôs hesitation. üëå

@Jim

Yeah, I have it easier with your name, don't U
I üòÉ

I get nostalgia. In my 1980s childhood there practically wasn't any chocolate to be had in Poland - probably because cocoa was not grown in any Eastern Bloc country. I still loved what chocolate-like products there were - and that was their actual name: "wyr√≥b czekoladopodobny". I remember and long for the taste even though it wasn't anything special by today's standards. It was the taste of the treats of my childhood, and it will always remain so.
*I have it easier with your name, don't I*

@Andrzej Sara Lee provides paid vacation and maternity leave like most American corporations. And their pound cake at least does not use high fructose corn syrup, does contain butter, and the ingredients list is pretty limited for a mass produced product. And pretty sure no orangutans were harmed in its production.

@Lewis

@Nancy J.

The crossword ethosphere zeitgeist.

Some days,
it is downright creepy.

@CCNY and @Nancy J.
Here's another one; one of the words I guessed in today's Wordle was ABASH, and ten minutes later it showed up as an answer in today's crossword.

@D  What do you consider "a musical background"?  I don't have one of those, or at least I don't think I do, and had no trouble solving the puzzle. As for puzzle themes, they are always wasted on  me. Maybe that means I don't have a thematic background?

@redweather If you don‚Äôt know the circled clues, the theme becomes ineffective and does not help solve the puzzle, and thus the puzzle effectively becomes themeless for the solver. Happy you had no trouble. You definitely aren‚Äôt humble bragging, right?
@D Solving a Tuesday puzzle is nothing to brag about. I was simply noting that despite your complaint about the puzzle, I solved it without any trouble.

@D

There are many, many puzzles in which the theme meant nothing to me. Or, where the majority of the clues are cultural (such as sports or rap groups) and so they mean nothing to me. That doesn't mean I can't or won't solve the puzzle. Instead, it broadens my knowledge. I would never have known what "Lil NasX" meant otherwise, or cared about any of the sports organizations. Well, still don't care, but I know enough to use them. Crosswords are fun AND a chance to learn something new. Keep building those synapses between neurons in your brain to stay healthy and live better, longer!
@redweather How illuminating.

@Marlene If you don‚Äôt know something, you don‚Äôt know it. Of course you learn after the fact. Why are you assuming I don‚Äôt take the opportunity to learn something? Such weird responses to my post, and of course people only selectively respond to what I write. Eye roll.

@D

I'm sorry, D. Looking it over, I think I responded to the wrong commenter! My apologies!

Steve,
I've noted this before. 
xwstats "expects" everyone to get faster quickly, so a puzzle doesn't get called EASY until the median is 18%-20% faster. OTOH, 1% slower is called HARD. "Very Easy" and "Very Hard" are also skewed. Thus, AVERAGE is not really average.

Steve,
I'm guessing they only use the median solve time (skewed as noted above). That would make it easier to fathom, but no less absurd.

@The X-Phile
That was lovely, plus fascinating to ‚Äòwatch‚Äô.

@The X-Phile

That was terrific!  Thanks!

Has anyone read "G√∂del, Escher, Bach:  an Eternal Golden Braid", by Douglas Hofstadter?

If I recall correctly Hofstadter writes one paragraph in the style of Bach's Fugue in G minor, with the characters saying things in fugue.  

What I remember most clearly are those long whole notes, where he has the character singing it saying "Gee!" as if surprise by something another character said.

üòÄYeah, that description sucked.  *You* try to describe a word fugue in words.

@Helen Wright

Correction:  Hofstadter wrote a *chapter* not a paragraph, in fugue form.

@Barry Ancona I understand, but from my limited solving experience it seems like the rule is that an abbreviation or acronym must be clued as such no matter how common it is. For example, even in today's puzzle, the clue for ATMS pointedly includes the symbols ‚Äú$$$‚Äù as abbreviation for ‚Äúcash‚Äù or ‚Äúmoney,‚Äù even though no-one says ‚Äúautomated teller machines‚Äù anymore.

userLocation: Spring training again. Ahh, at last! ‚öæÔ∏è
commentBody:
@saarl
My rule of thumb: if you don't use periods to show the abbreviation in writing, no need for an abbreviation indicator in the clue. Thus, BLT, not B.L.T. and ATM, not A.T.M.  So no need to clue either with 'in short' or 'briefly'.

@saarl

While I agree with all of the previous comments ‚Äì and it's great that you enjoyed the Sunday clue! ‚Äì I'd say the thing in favor of your original comment is that there is more support in the early-week clues. On a Tuesday, I'd expect an indicator of some kind... Not a personal quibble, just supporting your initial line of thought.
@Alfie B https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-because-or-since
Crossword clues are hints to answers; they need not be and most often are not their synonyms.

@Alfie B SINCE you mention it: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/since Entry 2, definition 3. See also: https://www.merriam-webster.com/grammar/since-as-because-usage Prescriptionists have been trying to tell us that "since" cannot mean "because," it's been used that way since Shakespeare's time, and in fact, the Bard himself used it. https://grammarphobia.com/blog/2015/07/since.html

commentBody:

Prescriptivist checking in here. The since/because mel√©e is the two-word embodiment of 'post hoc ergo propter hoc.' But since no one bothers with logical fallacies or, indeed, logic these days,  I agree that ship has sailed.

I really like this one, as a poem on its own merits. More than just a "like" as I scroll past!
